STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 24, 2021
Laura Nye
Hillsdale County DHHS
40 Care Drive
Hillsdale, MI 49242
RE: License #: CP300201172
Hillsdale County DHHS
40 Care Drive
Hillsdale, MI 49242
Dear Ms. Nye:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 03/15/21.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and Modified
Implementation, Sustainability and Exit Plan (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective
action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also
violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days
from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 For repeat violations note why the previous CAP was unsuccessful.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (269) 337-5289.
Sincerely,
Kari Muntean, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 395-0920
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP300201172
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Elizabeth Hertel, Designee
Name of Facility: Hillsdale County DHHS
Facility Address: 40 Care Drive
Hillsdale, MI 49242
Facility Telephone #: (517) 439-2200
Original Issuance Date: 06/01/1992
Service Types: PLACE CHILDREN FOR ADOPTION
CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
EVALUATE APPLICANTS FOR ADOPTION
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION – A. Consultant
Date of On-site Inspection(s): Teams entrance meeting 02/09/20, onsite 02/11/21, Teams
exit meeting 03/15/21

3

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(d) Three references obtained from persons who are unrelated
to the staff person.
One of six new employee/intern files reviewed contained only two references.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(h) A copy of the current children's foster home license
application and children's foster home licensing transaction
record documents from the certifying agency.
One of three borrowed bed files reviewed did not contain the current application and
licensing transaction record. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report 02/25/20, and
CAP 03/05/20. The agency must identify why the previous CAP failed and how
they are going to ensure compliance.
R 400.12403 Policy and procedures.
(2) The policies and procedures shall cover at least all of the
following areas:
(i) Service plans.
4

Four of seven applicable, current foster care files reviewed had the following
violations related to signatures on service and treatment plans:
 Two of four applicable files reviewed for signatures of youth 14 and older
were found to have undated or missing signatures, or service/treatment plans
that were not uploaded so I was unable to verify signatures.
 Three of five applicable files were found to have missing parental signatures
on treatment plans, or plans that were not uploaded to determine compliance.
 Two of seven applicable files contained caregiver/foster parent signatures
that were obtained late, or only had one of two caregiver signatures, or the
treatment plan was not uploaded to determine compliance.
 Three of eight files contained supervisor signatures that were completed late
by one or two days. One of the files did not have two signed plans uploaded.
REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report 02/25/20, and CAP 03/05/20 and Interim
Report, dated 03/27/19, and corresponding CAP, dated 04/15/19. The agency
must identify why the previous CAP failed and how they are going to ensure
compliance.
R 400.12404 Placement.
(7) An agency shall document, in the child's record, within 7
calendar days after placement, the information specified in R
400.12417(1) and all of the following information:
(a) All of the following child characteristics:
(iii) Height and weight.
(iv) Eye color and hair color.
(v) Identifying marks.
(vi) Religious preference.
(vii) School status, including grade, last school attended,
and educational program.
(b) Name, known addresses and marital status of the child’s
parents or legal guardian, if any.
(d) Known names, addresses, and dates of any previous out-
of-home placements.
5

One of three applicable foster care files reviewed for initial placement
documentation, was found not to have completed all of the required information and
omitted height and weight, eye color and hair color, identifying marks, religious
preference, school status, including grade, last school attended, and educational
program, name, known addresses and marital status of the child’s parents or legal
guardian, if any, and known names, addresses, and dates of any previous out-of-
home placements. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report 02/25/20, and CAP
03/05/20 and Interim Report, dated 03/27/19, and corresponding CAP, dated
04/15/19. The agency must identify why the previous CAP failed and how they
are going to ensure compliance.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(a) Reason for the change in placement.
(b) If the child is not returned to the parent, then the reason
why return is not possible.
(c) If the child is not reunited with siblings or placed with a
relative, then the reason why those placements are not
possible.
(d) Consideration of the factors identified in R 400.12404(4).
(e) Replacement preparation, regardless of the child’s age,
appropriate to the child’s capacity to understand, which includes
an explanation to all relevant parties as to why the change is
necessary.
(f) Notification to the parents, referral source, lawyer
guardian ad litem, and courts when applicable, of the change in
placement.
(g) Information about the child was shared with the new
placement, consistent with the requirements of R 400.12417
(h) The child’s new location and address.
(i) That the current foster parent was notified in writing of the
following information:
(i) Not less than 14 calendar days in advance, of the
change, except when prior notification would jeopardize the
child’s care or safety. If prior notice is not provided, then the
agency shall notify the foster parent, at the time of the change,
why prior notice was not given.
(ii) Of the current foster parent’s rights concerning the
change in placement.
(j) Supervisory approval before the change.
(4) If an emergency change in placement is necessary, then all
of the documentation required in subrules (2) and (3) of this rule
shall be in the child’s record within 14 calendar days after the
change in placement.
6

Two of three current foster care files reviewed for four changes in child placement
were found to be missing (1) or completed the required documentation late (1) for
the change, as required on the DHHS 69 Action Summary. REPEAT VIOLATION,
Renewal Report 02/25/20, and CAP 03/05/20 and Interim Report, dated 03/27/19,
and corresponding CAP, dated 04/15/19. The agency must identify why the
previous CAP failed and how they are going to ensure compliance.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any treatment
required for each child who is 4 years of age and older,
including both of the following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be completed not
more than 90 calendar days after placement.
(ii) A dental reexamination shall be obtained at least every
18 months, unless a greater frequency is indicated.
*DHHS Policy FOM 801 outlines that annual dental exams are
to be completed annually for youth aged three and older.
Four of five current and applicable foster care files reviewed for dental examinations
were found not to have the required exams in the record. One of the four files was
found to be missing the initial examination and an annual exam. The other three files
were found to be missing the last annual exams. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal
Report 02/25/20, and CAP 03/05/20. The agency must identify why the previous
CAP failed and how they are going to ensure compliance.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child:
(a) Child's name.
(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating to
the care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement
of the child.
7

(h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent
to provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the
foster child and the foster family, including information
about siblings who do not reside in the foster home.
(i) Name of assigned social service worker.
One of four applicable foster care files reviewed did not contain documentation that
the required information was provided to the foster parent at, or before, the time of
placement.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
(a) Two of three current and applicable foster care files reviewed contained initial
plans that were completed late by one and four days, respectively.
(b) Five of seven current and applicable foster care files reviewed contained updated
plans that were completed late by 1, 3, 12, 23, and 25 days, respectively. REPEAT
VIOLATION, Renewal Report 02/25/20, and CAP 03/05/20. The agency must
identify why the previous CAP failed and how they are going to ensure
compliance.
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and parenting
time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster child
and the foster parent in the foster parent's home at least once
every month.
One of eight current foster care files reviewed was missing a face-to-face visit for
one month during the review period. This was not found for face-to-face or video
conferenced visit.
R 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement to a
youth before placement in independent living.
One of one independent living file was found not to have provided the program
statement until 01/08/21, when the youth was placed in independent living 09/02/20.
8

R 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living with a
copy of the agency’s policies and procedures required by this
rule.
One of one independent living file was found not to have provided the program
policies and procedures until 01/08/21, when the youth was placed in independent
living on 09/02/20.
R 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following information
and documentation, which shall be recorded within 30 calendar
days after placement in independent living and updated at least
once every 90 calendar days:
(g) Current documentation of financial support sufficient
to meet the youth's housing, clothing, food, and
miscellaneous expenses.
One of one independent living files reviewed did not contain documentation that the
youth was managing expenses and had sufficient financial support.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(1) There shall be a mutually agreed upon contract between
the youth and the agency specifying all of the following:
(a) The responsibilities of the agency and the youth.
(d) The location where the youth is living.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
9

(1)(2) One of one independent living files reviewed was missing an initial contract
from the youth entering independent living and the next quarterly contract was done
about a month late. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report 02/25/20, and CAP
03/05/20 and Interim Report, dated 03/27/19, and corresponding CAP, dated
04/15/19. The agency must identify why the previous CAP failed and how they
are going to ensure compliance.
(1)(d) The one contract in the one independent living youth’s file did not specify the
location where the youth is living.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
ISEP 6.43 - Page 32 – Medical and Mental Health Examinations
Two of five current and applicable foster care cases reviewed for annual well child
exams were found to be missing the exams for the last year. One of the two files
was found to be missing the exam for the last two years.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included
in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
DHHS Policy FOM 801 – Medical Passports
Eight of eight current foster care files, and one of one current independent living
files reviewed, were found to have missing and/or late medical passports as
required. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report 02/25/20, and CAP 03/05/20
and Interim Report, dated 03/27/19, and corresponding CAP, dated 04/15/19.
The agency must identify why the previous CAP failed and how they are
going to ensure compliance.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-06H - CASEWORKER CONTACT CHILD IN OUT-OF-
HOME PLACEMENT
One of four applicable foster care files reviewed for initial placement or
replacement was found to be missing face-to-face contacts with the child in the
second 30 days after one of the youth’s placement changes. A visit was done for
the calendar month, but the two required contacts were not completed during the
second 30-day period.
10

DHHS Policy - FOM 722-06H - CASEWORKER CONTACT WITH PARENT(S)/
GUARDIAN(S)
Four of four applicable foster care files reviewed were found to be missing face-to-
face visits with the parents in the parental home.
DHHS Policy 722-06B - Family Team Meetings (FTM).
Six of eight current foster care files and one of one independent living files
reviewed were found to having missing/late FTMs, FTM reports that were not
uploaded, FTMs done more than 30 days prior to the applicable service plan for
which they were conducted, and/or FTMs that only had the worker with the youth
or parent and not a full team. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal Report 02/25/20,
and CAP 03/05/20 and Interim Report, dated 03/27/19, and corresponding
CAP, dated 04/15/19. The agency must identify why the previous CAP failed
and how they are going to ensure compliance.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-06H - TIMELY ENTRY OF CASEWORKER
CONTACTS
Five of eight foster care files reviewed were found to have social work contacts
entered late (beyond the five business days permitted). These contacts were
observed to be between 1 and 79 days late. REPEAT VIOLATION, Renewal
Report 02/25/20, and CAP 03/05/20 and Interim Report, dated 03/27/19, and
corresponding CAP, dated 04/15/19. The agency must identify why the
previous CAP failed and how they are going to ensure compliance.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R 312
The agency is advised to closely track CPR/First Aid training to ensure that foster
parents are up to date on an ongoing basis and not just at annual/renewal
inspections.
R 326
The agency is advised to ensure that the foster parent’s request for closure and
original licensing transaction record are uploaded with the closing documents.
11

V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
No consultation was requested.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care or substantiated
corporal punishment during this licensing period.
The agency has submitted 0 acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. There have been no special investigations
of this agency.
The DCWL Field Analyst report noted no safety concerns or follow up needed.
The agency has 19 violations in this inspection which is the same as the last
inspection. There are 10 repeat violations compared to 11 in the last inspection. Of
the 10 repeat violations, 7 are a violation for the 3rd consecutive year. The agency
should take care to focus on the repeat violations and why the prior CAPs were not
effective, to bring them into compliance.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
March 23, 2021
________________________________________
Kari Muntean Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
March 24, 2021
________________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
12
